Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Dynamics and Spectroscopy on Multiple Potential Energy Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Richard Dawes of the Missouri University of Science and Technology is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry division to develop theoretical methods to study molecular dynamics and spectroscopy on multiple potential energy surfaces (PESs). Dawes and his research group are working to develop robust methods and software to construct accurate coupled multistate PESs. This involves systematic studies of systems which include various non-adiabatic interactions between states such as conical intersections, Renner-Teller, and spin-orbit coupling to assess the importance of such effects. The study compares cases where non-adiabatic effects provide an alternate mechanism (usually assumed to be a minor channel), with cases such as the reaction of triplet oxygen atoms with carbon monoxide to form carbon dioxide where the spin-forbidden channel is the only one available.

The potential energy surface (PES) is central to how chemists think about the structure and dynamics of molecular systems, in terms of minima and asymptotes connected by paths across landscapes or over energetic barriers. This project investigates systems for which subtle details of the PES topography and interactions between more than one of such surfaces have profound effects on reaction kinetics and on understanding and interpreting the dynamics. The project also focusses on making efficient use of many computer processors to solve the problem of generating accurate PESs for radicals and species with unusual bonding and electronic structures (particularly those of interest to atmospheric and interstellar chemistry). This will make the complete development of global PESs and subsequent quantum dynamics studies much more rapid and routine than is currently possible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There were two major method development goals related to the project titled “Molecular Dynamics and Spectroscopy on Multiple Potential Energy Surfaces”.

1) Development of robustly applicable electronic structure methods in the context of multistate potential energy surfaces (PESs).

Dynamically weighted MRCI (DW-MRCI):

This part of the project involves developing and applying ideas based on the DW-MRCI multistate electronic structure scheme to construct accurate PESs for systems in which the interactions of multiple states play an important role in the observed spectroscopy and dynamics. This includes cases such as ozone (O3) and formyl radical (HCO) where the interactions between multiple states significantly influence the topography even of the ground state and play important roles in atmospheric dynamics, as well as systems such as MgC where multiple strongly-coupled electronic states give rise to highly mixed vibronic states that are difficult to interpret by spectroscopists without theoretical support.  

 The dynamically weighted MRCI approach has reached a high level of reliability. I am now consulting with others on how to apply it to systems of interest where other methods fail. We published a review article in International Reviews in Physical Chemistry that provides several examples of how to deal with tricky electronic structure problems and describes some of our best procedures in detail. Our work on the (now barrierless) transition region of ozone has been recognized as a qualitative step forward in how the community interprets the dynamics of this system. The PI was invited to the board of organizers for an international workshop on ozone in Reims, France.

2) Potential energy surface construction methods

A second aspect of the project relates to the construction of PESs using data generated by the methods described in part 1) above. This involves development of automated fitting algorithms using parallel computing to efficiently construct highly accurate PESs. Codes were refined that allow the PES to be generated with minimal human intervention. Test systems include vdWs dimers which are useful fitting accuracy benchmarks since the electronic structure is typically very well behaved thus eliminating the issue of questionable data and allowing one to easily assess different fitting strategies. Other research directions include treating multi-channel reactive PESs with more atoms as well as treating high permutation symmetry by combining with methods such as permutation invariant polynomials (PIP). This part of the project was particularly successful and making the software user-friendly, robust and freely available is the subject of renewal project CHE-1566246. We have recently submitted an invited book chapter to Revs. in Comp. Chem. on PES construction intended for the new graduate student audience.   

Over the duration of this project we have made significant progress in all of the focus areas. A total of 23 publications (solely citing NSF support) were produced and significant momentum was carried forward into the ongoing CHE-1566246 project.

The project has supported several graduate students. Phalgun Lolur graduated last year and is working as a postdoc with Bill Green at MIT. Andrew Powell also graduated with his Ph.D. and will begin a postdoc position at Leiden University in the Netherlands in January. Moumita Majumder (postdoc) has taken a faculty position back in India. All of the trainees benefited from attending and presenting at conferences and were involved in highly relevant published research.
